Regarding the constitutionality, you could apply the necessary and proper clause here and say that the federal government should at least set some standards for the states.

 
 Actually, I disagree with this. Obviously, the government COULD apply the elastic clause [and probably would if the issue was ever brought up], but I don't think that they should be allowed to do this.
 
 I may be completely wrong - after all, I'm not a political scholar or anything - but this is my opinion:
 
 The Elastic Clause and the IX Amendment are part of the same document, were enacted at virtually the same time, etc. The EC says the fed. gov. can enact any laws they want to, and IX says that the fed. gov. has only those rights defined in the Constitution. Although it would seem like they are contradictory at first sight, I have a hard time believing that [because of the fact that they're part of the same document, were put in place at the same time, etc.]. Thus, there must be SOME distinct difference.
 
 This is the best I've come up with:
 
 The Framers of the Constitution wanted it to last many generations. So, obviously, it would have to adapt. The EC, in my opinion, gives Congress power to make laws over things that arise in the future. Over things that they couldn't possibly predict back then. Things such as airline security, Internet regulation, stuff like that.
 
 However, I think that the IX Amendment is different in the fact that it applies more to "generic" stuff. Things like education and health care aren't something new. They've been around virtually forever. That's why I believe that education is a state/local right.
 
 Like I said, I'm not an expert in this stuff - that's just what I've gotten out of it. There must be SOME different between the EC and the IX, and that's the best I could come up with.
